interface.name: zwp_text_input_v3
interface.description:
The zwp_text_input_v3 interface represents text input and input methods associated with a seat. It provides enter/leave events to follow the text input focus for a seat.
Requests are used to enable/disable the text-input object and set state information like surrounding and selected text or the content type. The information about the entered text is sent to the text-input object via the pre-edit and commit_string events.
Text is valid UTF-8 encoded, indices and lengths are in bytes. Indices have to always point to the first byte of an UTF-8 encoded code point. Lengths are not allowed to contain just a part of an UTF-8 encoded code point.
Focus moving throughout surfaces will result in the emission of zwp_text_input_v3.enter and zwp_text_input_v3.leave events. The focused surface must perform zwp_text_input_v3.enable and zwp_text_input_v3.disable requests as the keyboard focus moves across editable and non-editable elements of the UI. Those two requests are not expected to be paired with each other, the compositor must be able to handle consecutive series of the same request.
State is sent by the state requests (set_surrounding_text, set_content_type and set_cursor_rectangle) and a commit request. After an enter event or disable request all state information is invalidated and needs to be resent by the client.
This protocol defines requests and events necessary for regular clients to communicate with an input method. The zwp_input_method protocol defines the interfaces necessary to implement standalone input methods. If a compositor implements both interfaces, it will be the arbiter of the communication between both.
Warning! The protocol described in this file is experimental and backward incompatible changes may be made. Backward compatible changes may be added together with the corresponding interface version bump. Backward incompatible changes are done by bumping the version number in the protocol and interface names and resetting the interface version. Once the protocol is to be declared stable, the 'z' prefix and the version number in the protocol and interface names are removed and the interface version number is reset.

request.name: destroy
request.description: Destroy the wp_text_input object. Also disables all surfaces enabled through this wp_text_input object.

enum.name: enable_flags
enum.description: Enable flags is a bitmask to allow to modify the behavior of the text input.

entry.name: can_show_preedit
entry.summary: hints that the UI is capable of showing pre-edit text

entry.name: toggle_input_panel
entry.summary: requests toggling input panel (eg. on-screen keyboard)

request.name: enable

description.summary: Request text input to be enabled

request.description: Requests text input on a surface.

request.name: disable

description.summary: Disable text input on a surface

request.description: Explicitly disable text input in a surface (typically when there is no focus on any text entry inside the surface).

request.name: set_surrounding_text
request.description:
Sets the surrounding plain text around the input position. Text is UTF-8 encoded. Cursor is the byte offset within the surrounding text. Anchor is the byte offset of the selection anchor within the surrounding text. If there is no selected text, anchor is the same as cursor.
Make sure to always send some text before and after the cursor except when the cursor is at the beginning or end of text.
There is a maximum length of wayland messages so text can not be longer than 4000 bytes.
Values set with this request are double-buffered. They will get applied on the next zwp_text_input_v3.commit request.
The initial value for text is an empty string, and the initial values for cursor and anchor are 0.

enum.name: content_hint
enum.description: Content hint is a bitmask to allow to modify the behavior of the text input.

entry.name: auto_capitalization
entry.summary: switch to uppercase letters at the start of a sentence

entry.name: titlecase
entry.summary: prefer casing for titles and headings (can be language dependent)

entry.name: sensitive_data
entry.summary: typed text should not be stored

entry.name: latin
entry.summary: just Latin characters should be entered

enum.name: content_purpose
enum.description:
The content purpose allows to specify the primary purpose of a text input.
This allows an input method to show special purpose input panels with extra characters or to disallow some characters.

entry.name: number
entry.summary: input a number (including decimal separator and sign)

entry.name: name
entry.summary: input a name of a person

entry.name: password
entry.summary: input a password (combine with sensitive_data hint)

entry.name: pin
entry.summary: input is a numeric password (combine with sensitive_data hint)

request.name: set_content_type
request.description:
Sets the content purpose and content hint. While the purpose is the basic purpose of an input field, the hint flags allow to modify some of the behavior.
Values set with this request are double-buffered. They will get applied on the next zwp_text_input_v3.commit request.
The initial value for hint is none, and the initial value for purpose is normal.

request.name: set_cursor_rectangle
request.description:
Sets the cursor outline as a x, y, width, height rectangle in surface local coordinates.
Allows the compositor to put a window with word suggestions near the cursor.
Values set with this request are double-buffered. They will get applied on the next zwp_text_input_v3.commit request.
The initial values describing a cursor rectangle are invalid. That means the pending cursor rectangle values must be set before the first commit request.

request.name: commit
request.description:
Text input state (content purpose, content hint, surrounding text, cursor rectangle) is conceptually double-buffered. Protocol requests modify the pending state, as opposed to the current state in use by the input method. A commit request atomically applies all pending state, replacing the current state. After commit, the new pending state is as documented for each related request.
The current and pending state never changes unless noted otherwise.

event.name: enter
event.description:
Notification that this seat's text-input focus is on a certain surface.
When the seat has the keyboard capability the text-input focus follows the keyboard focus.

event.name: leave
event.description:
Notification that this seat's text-input focus is no longer on a certain surface. The client should reset any preedit string previously set.
The leave notification is sent before the enter notification for the new focus.
When the seat has the keyboard capability the text-input focus follows the keyboard focus.

event.name: preedit_string
event.description: Notify when a new composing text (pre-edit) should be set around the current cursor position. Any previously set composing text should be removed.

event.name: commit_string
event.description:
Notify when text should be inserted into the editor widget. The text to commit could be either just a single character after a key press or the result of some composing (pre-edit).
The text argument could be also null if some text is removed (see zwp_text_input_v3.delete_surrounding_text).
Any previously set composing text should be removed.

event.name: delete_surrounding_text
event.description:
Notify when the text around the current cursor position should be deleted. Before_length and after_length is the length (in bytes) of text before and after the current cursor position (excluding the selection) to delete.
This event should be handled as part of a following commit_string or preedit_string event.

arg.name: before_length
arg.summary: length of text before current cursor position

arg.name: after_length
arg.summary: length of text after current cursor position

interface.name: zwp_text_input_manager_v3
interface.description: A factory for text-input objects. This object is a global singleton.

request.description: Creates a new text-input object for a given seat.
